733252f-a.title: Squatters Colony at the Hudson River.
733252f-a.text:
Squatters Colony, Manhattan: An unemployed individuals lodging place on the Hudson River embankment near the Fort Lee Bridge (George Washington Bridge at West 181st Street).
October 5, 1930.
P.L. Sperr.
733252f-a.folder: 181st Street and Riverside Drive, Manhattan, N.Y.

722852f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, east side, north of Plaza Lafayette, (181st Street,)
showing a frame house.
September 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722851f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, north from but not including Plaza Lafayette (West 181st Street). On the extreme right appear the stone wall and ornamental columns of the estate of Dr. Charles V. Paterno, which has its entrance on Northern Ave. This wall was built in about 1920. There is a capacious residence built on the style of an ancient Italian castle and many greenhouses, which the doctor maintains as a hobby.
December 28, 1934.
Irving Fitterman.

722853f-a.text:
Riverside Drive, south from but not including 181st Street, showing
Plaza Lafayette.
June 3, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

715788f-a.text:
West 181st Street, west from No. 867, a structure midway between Riverside Drive and Northern Ave., across Northern Ave., to Pinehurst Ave. The building appearing on the right is the Fort View, No. 854, at the S.E. corner of Northern Ave.
November 18, 1936
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

715789f-a.text:
875 West 181st Street, at the N.E. corner of Riverside Drive, as viewed northward from Haven Ave. This structure, the Stirling Towers, consists of several units; the main entrance being shown on the left. Appearing partially on the right is the Dunncraggan, No. 867, midway between the Drive and Northern Ave.
November 18, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

722854f-b.text:
Riverside Drive, north from a point to the north of W. 181st Street showing this sweepirg thoroughfare skirting the North (Hudson) River. At the right is an inclined roadway (Riverside Terrace) that leads to the apartment house section, known as Washington Heights and from which the new George Washington Bridge projects across the river to New Jersey. The enbanked colonnade forms a portion of Dr. Chas. V. Paterno's estate and same will remain after demolition in 1938 of this individuals castle-like home. He, being a real-estate operator will improve this site with a series of modern garden apartments, similar to his Hudson View Gardens of the same vicinity. View 3 is a vista from the pergola during the aforementioned operation. For additional views taken during this construction period, see, files under Cabrini Boulevard ( a new name
for Northern Avenue since 1938).
June 3, 1934
Views 1 and 2
View 3: August 23, 1938.
P.L. Sperr
